Key Arguments: The bill infringes on freedom of speech and expression.
It creates a divide between citizens, privileging certain groups like politicians and journalists.
The bill imposes excessive fines and lacks mechanisms to address its potential harms.
It is difficult to accurately distinguish between true and false information due to the evolving nature of knowledge.
The bill could be exploited by large digital service providers to stifle competition.
The extraterritorial application is impractical and inconsistent with international cooperation.
The bill contradicts the News Media Bargaining Code, undermining government credibility.
Notable Quotes: This is the stuff that dictatorships and communist regimes want in place.
The internet is one of the most powerful democratic inventions in human history.
The bill divides citizens into two classes, privileging the viewpoints of government-approved institutions.
